thread.title: St. Louis board approves mosque development in historic district — with no wall
thread.title_full: St. Louis board approves mosque development in historic district — with no wall

author: Tim Bryant St. Louis Post-Dispatch
title: St. Louis board approves mosque development in historic district — with no wall
text:
Rendering of mosque planned in McKinley Heights neighborhood St. Louis board approves mosque development in historic district — with no wall ( … ) 
Rendering of mosque planned in McKinley Heights neighborhood 
Security concerns and rules governing new construction in a St. Louis historic district bumped Monday over plans to build a small mosque. 
Qooba Foundation wants to build the one-story mosque on a vacant lot it owns at Allen and South Jefferson avenues, at the edge of the city’s McKinley Heights Historic District. 
Foundation leaders and neighborhood residents expressed their varied opinions before the St. Louis Preservation Board. In the end, both sides got at least part of what they wanted. 
The city’s Cultural Resources Office had recommended that the board approve Qooba’s plan even though the mosque would be at the rear of the site instead of at the corner, as required by historic district rules. 
In its report, the office’s staff said “concern regarding the safety of the congregants is the reason the (Qooba Foundation) seeks an exception to the requirement that the building be located at the street and on the corner.” Qooba’s plan places the mosque — angled to face Mecca — at the rear of the site, with parking in front. 
The Cultural Resources Office report had urged construction of a brick perimeter wall next to the site’s sidewalks to screen the parking from view and to continue “the building lines of the block.” 
Members of the mosque’s congregation and neighborhood residents agreed Monday that the recommended 8-foot-high brick wall was a bad idea. 
Tim Kaminiski, Qooba Foundation’s president, told board members such a wall would likely be a target of vandals. Other congregation members said they preferred a lower wall or no wall.
